author: By Christopher Garis and David Fernández
title: A House in Tangier Untethered From Time and Place
description: With the help of a Casablancan designer, one expat art dealer creates a home that’s always undergoing its next update.
content: IN THE COLLECTIVE Western imagination, Morocco is arid and desertlike, the clay-walled labyrinths of Marrakesh’s medina standing in for the entire country. But Tangier, 350 miles to the city’s north, at the edge of the Rif Mountains where the Atlantic meets the Mediterranean, is humid: Torrential rains fall from New Year’s to Easter, and then sporadically the rest of the year. Wallpaper bubbles, paint flakes and shoes left in the back of the closet turn green with mold. In summer, plumes of fog hover over the Casbah, the city’s historic walled fortress.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin
title: The Missing Piece in the Push for Boardroom Diversity
description: Private companies are lagging behind publicly traded firms, but don’t receive the same scrutiny.
content: Last summer, major public companies across the country pledged to increase diversity in their boardrooms, one of the actions taken after the murder of George Floyd in police custody. Corporate directors set goals, and some have begun to make progress, with investors, activists and others tracking their commitments on racial equity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Kitroeff and Oscar Lopez
title: Mexico’s Supreme Court Votes to Decriminalize Abortion
description: The ruling, which sets a precedent for the legalization of abortion nationwide, follows years of efforts by a growing women’s movement in Mexico.
content: MEXICO CITY — Criminalizing abortion is unconstitutional, Mexico’s Supreme Court ruled on Tuesday, setting a precedent that could lead to legalization of the procedure across this conservative Catholic country of about 130 million people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elaine Glusac
title: The Trouble With Airports, and How to Fix Them
description: With all the aggravation associated with flying these days, airport designers are hoping to calm things down with outdoor spaces, wide-open views, less noise and even foliage.
content: During this summer of frequent flight delays and cancellations, many travelers spent more time in airports than expected, often subjected to blaring TV news, rock-hard seats and scarce electrical outlets. Add anxiety over Covid-19 and disagreements regarding mandated masking and it’s little wonder incidents of bad behavior have surged in the air. The Federal Aviation Administration reported more than 4,000 cases of unruly passenger complaints this year through August, initiating more than 700 investigations to date, compared to 183 in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shashank Bengali
title: A global network of activists calls for November U.N. climate talks to be postponed over pandemic concerns.
description: The Climate Action Network said coronavirus conditions would mean many representatives would not be able to attend the annual conference, set this year for Scotland.
content: A global network of activists called on Tuesday for international climate talks scheduled for November in Scotland to be postponed, arguing that delegates from the most vulnerable nations would not be able to attend because of the pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: Australians denounce their prime minister for a trip to see his family during lockdown.
description: Scott Morrison said he was within the rules to travel to his home state without quarantining over the weekend that included Australia’s Father’s Day.
content: Prime Minister Scott Morrison defended traveling to his home state for Australian Father’s Day over the weekend, prompting a backlash in a country where millions of people have been unable to see loved ones because of strict measures against Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: How Michael K. Williams Made Omar Little His Own on ‘The Wire’
description: Williams and his colleagues on the show once spoke about how the role evolved for an oral history of the series.
content: The first time the casting director Alexa Fogel saw the actor Michael K. Wiliams, he was auditioning for a small role in the HBO drama “Oz.” He did not get the part.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ephrat Livni and Oscar Lopez
title: El Salvador’s Adoption of Bitcoin Is Off to a Rocky Start
description: Experts had raised concerns about making the digital token an official currency and the rapid execution of new technology on a national scale.
content: El Salvador faced a rocky transition in its adoption of Bitcoin as legal tender on Tuesday. The government’s app for facilitating transactions — its “digital wallet” — went offline temporarily, protesters took to the streets of the capital to denounce the move, and the price of Bitcoin dropped sharply, demonstrating the volatility of the cryptocurrency market.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal
title: A Presidential Visit and a Promise of Federal Aid
description: Ahead of President Biden's visit, the governors of New York and New Jersey announced that they had been granted storm-recovery funds.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley, Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li
title: Warning of Income Gap, Xi Tells China’s Tycoons to Share Wealth
description: As the country’s leader prepares for a likely third term, he is promising “common prosperity” to lift farmers and working families into the middle class.
content: Four decades ago, Deng Xiaoping declared that China would “let some people get rich first” in its race for growth. Now, Xi Jinping has put China’s tycoons on notice that it is time for them to share more wealth with the rest of the country.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Transcript of Biden’s Speech on Climate Change and Hurricane Ida
description: “The nation and the world are in peril,” President Biden said after touring storm damage in New York and Jersey. “And that’s not hyperbole. That is a fact.”
content: The following is a transcript of President Biden’s remarks about climate change and Hurricane Ida after he toured damage from the storm in neighborhoods in New York and New Jersey on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost and Whet Moser
title: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Britain’s likely tax hike.
content: Britain’s Boris Johnson is widely expected to break his vow not to increase taxes today when he announces a plan to bolster the nation’s social care services, a longtime goal that he first unveiled soon after becoming prime minister in 2019.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Gorman
title: How the Cat Gets Its Stripes: It’s Genetics, Not a Folk Tale
description: Researchers took a deep dive into embryonic development to tease out the source of the tabby pattern in cats.
content: Folklore is full of stories about the coat patterns of cats: How the tiger got its stripes. How the leopard got its spots. And scientists ask the same questions, although not necessarily about large predators. The research may focus instead on something like the mackerel tabby pattern in domestic shorthairs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley
title: Despite the Cosby Ruling, Andrea Constand Feels Like a ‘Symbol of Hope’
description: As she releases her memoir, Constand details her reactions to the court decision that overturned Bill Cosby’s conviction on sexual assault charges.
content: The call came just before noon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Juliet Macur
title: ‘This is code red.’ Biden visits areas of New York and New Jersey hit hard by Ida.
description: “The nation and the world are in peril,” President Biden said as he visited Queens. “And that’s not hyperbole. That is a fact.”
content: President Biden warned Americans on Tuesday that Hurricane Ida’s lethal destruction was a sure sign of a nation and world “in peril” from climate change, and said drastic action would be needed to prevent extreme weather patterns from worsening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Eyre Ward
title: In Tokyo, a Bored Wife Seeks Excitement
description: Emily Itami’s debut novel asks an age-old question: Does marriage and kids mean monotony and obligation or is there room for one’s authentic self?
content: FAULT LINES By Emily Itami
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Niraj Chokshi, Matthew Goldstein and Erin Woo
title: Biden’s Electric Car Plans Hinge on Having Enough Chargers
description: The United States has about 100,000 public chargers, far fewer than Europe and China. It needs 10 times as many, auto experts say, to complete the switch from combustion engine vehicles.
content: In President Biden’s vision of a green future, half of all new cars sold in 2030 will be electric. But something really basic is standing in the way of that plan: enough outlets to plug in all those cars and trucks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Caramanica
title: Drake, in Search of an Enemy Besides Himself
description: His new album “Certified Lover Boy” is full of familiar anxieties and sounds, and barbed words for Kanye West, a mentor turned nemesis.
content: At this point in Drake’s career, there are songs about the throne, and songs about the bed. Each milieu comes with a price. The first is about hard power: Remaining at the top means outmaneuvering enemies, building up an invulnerable enterprise. The other, in Drake’s hands at least, is about soft power — most often, the path to conquest is through humility, and sometimes awe. Rarely do the two modes meet.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: The Taliban announce acting government posts.
content: The Taliban chose people to fill several cabinet positions on an acting basis, stopping short of formally announcing a permanent government in Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim McKeough
title: Before Renovating, They Had to Get Rid of the Current Occupants: Mice
description: Some $40,000 later, they could finally start thinking about updating the house they bought in Farmington, Conn.
content: Drew and Jeanne Barber thought they had found a heavenly place to raise their two young children when they toured a four-bedroom, 4,900-square-foot house on 11 acres in Farmington, Conn., in 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: One Great Summer Memory
description: Tell us about one wonderful moment, big or small, from the summer of 2021.
content: How was your summer? Instead of telling us about everything you did, we’re challenging you to focus on just one happy memory, big or small, and tell us about it in detail.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: Sept. 7, 2021
description: No corrections appeared in print on Tuesday, Sept. 7, 2021.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Here Comes the Autumn of Anxiety
description: The pandemic hasn’t ended; the rescue programs have.
content: In the heady days of spring, when the United States was vaccinating 3 million people a day, President Biden predicted a “summer of joy.” But then the vaccination campaign stalled, and the Delta variant fueled a new wave of infections, hospitalizations and deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Singal
title: Trans Rights and Gender Identity
description: In “Trans: When Ideology Meets Reality,” Helen Joyce argues that sex is not just a social construct.
content: TRANSWhen Ideology Meets RealityBy Helen Joyce
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Junction Points
description: Zhouqin Burnikel’s Tuesday puzzle cashes in.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Today’s column is brought to you by the letter C, as in “C.C.,” which is how Zhouqin Burnikel is known to her many fans. Ms. Burnikel, who is making her 73rd (!!) appearance in the New York Times Crossword, is a true professional, producing creative and engaging puzzles with an unparalleled ability to keep crossword “glue” to a bare minimum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: A Hall of Fame Shortstop, Through and Through
description: Over the years, Derek Jeter took plenty of criticism for his fielding. But his spot at the center of a Yankees dynasty was far from coincidental.
content: When it was all over in New York, after he singled home the winning run on his final swing, Derek Jeter at last turned nostalgic. For two decades, he had been the master of the moment, always pushing forward, never lingering on what it all meant. But now he had given his last performance on his favorite stage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Juliet Macur
title: In the flooded New Jersey town that Biden visited, residents feel forgotten.
description: It’s hard to find a single street in the working-class town of Manville that was not severely affected by flooding connected to Hurricane Ida.
content: MANVILLE, N.J. — In the aftermath of Hurricane Ida, it is hard to find a single neighborhood — or even a street — in the small central New Jersey town of Manville that was not severely affected by flooding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: NASA’s Perseverance Rover Stashes First Mars Rock Sample
description: The rock, sealed in a tube, is the first of many the robotic explorer will collect to one day send back to Earth for scientists to study.
content: NASA’s Perseverance rover on Mars has confirmed the successful collection of its first rock sample.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: From Afghanistan to the World Cup, Tiny, Wealthy Qatar Steps Up
description: The Gulf state played a major role in the American airlift, the latest evidence of the small but gas-rich country punching above its weight on the world stage.
content: DOHA, Qatar — As chaos took over the United States’ last-minute efforts to evacuate more than 120,000 of its citizens and partners from Afghanistan last month, a tiny, wealthy country that many Americans would struggle to find on a map suddenly found itself uniquely placed to help out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carol Rosenberg
title: Proceedings in 9/11 Case Resume, and Then Are Delayed Again
description: Days ahead of the 20th anniversary of the Sept. 11 attacks, the five men accused of plotting them returned to court after a long shutdown, only to have the hearing quickly recessed.
content: GUANTÁNAMO BAY, Cuba — It was supposed to be a hearing intended to get the case against the five men accused of plotting the Sept. 11 attacks back on track after a long delay caused by the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Shop for All Your Dinner Party Needs
description: Katherine Lewin opened Big Night, a bright store stocked with everything you need for entertaining.
content: After a year of the pandemic, Katherine Lewin, the former editorial director for the restaurant platform the Infatuation, missed dinner parties. Figuring she was not alone, Ms. Lewin opened a bright shop stocked with essentials for entertaining. “People are intimidated, but it can be easy,” she said. (Ms. Lewin readily dispenses advice.) Shelves are filled with food products like tinned seafood, crackers and condiments, and there is a refrigerator stocked with cured meats and cheeses. She also sells She Wolf breads. The central counter and the wall behind it hold flatware, dishes, cake stands, linen napkins, barware and glassware, including some vintage pieces. Behind the store there is a secluded outdoor area with benches and a big picnic table; she plans to hold events with local restaurants there. E-commerce is coming.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Court Hands Biden Relief From a Migrant Surge
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, September 7, 2021.
content: “They killed all our hope. The Biden government promised many things, and now we feel tricked.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Kaitlin Roberts, Lynsea Garrison, Clare Toeniskoetter, Eric Krupke, Neena Pathak, Lisa Chow, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Corey Schreppel
title: How Will the Taliban Rule This Time?
description: Now that most of the fighting is over, the group is turning to the task of building a government.
content: Since the Taliban took over Kabul, Afghanistan’s capital, last month, many have wondered what kind of rulers they will be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: Nensi Dojaka Wins LVMH Prize for Young Designers
description: The Albanian women’s wear designer, who courts a cult following with her barely-there mesh dresses and separates, scooped the industry’s most prestigious new talent award.
content: Nensi Dojaka, a 28-year-old Albanian women’s wear designer known for her distinctive barely-there mesh dresses and separates, has won the 2021 LVMH Prize for emerging talent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni and Anna Schaverien
title: Where Diversity Still Disappoints
description: Black directors have held only 1 percent of board seats at private companies backed by top venture capital and private equity firms.
content: Heightened attention to boardroom diversity at public companies has changed the makeup of the upper ranks of corporate America. Well-financed private businesses, however, haven’t faced the same scrutiny, and are lagging behind when it comes to adding diverse directors, Andrew writes in a new column.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seamas O'Reilly
title: Who Can Say Why Enya Endures? Only Time
description: Even at her peak, she was hugely famous but never especially cool. But maybe we’re finally ready to heed her whispered call to awaken.
content: On the long drives through Ireland that peppered my childhood like bouts of flu, my father played songs from a small pool of classic albums. Many of these would be familiar to any Irishman from that time. The cheerful ribaldry of the Dubliners, Christy Moore’s “Live at the Point” and the earnest, heart-tugging confessionals of Eleanor McEvoy and Mary Black all soundtracked our winding trips through the unending swatches of green that formed the Irish countryside. But none of those artists struck me like my father’s personal favorite, Enya.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Alphonso David, Who Advised Cuomo, Fired as Human Rights Campaign President
description: Mr. David, who previously worked as a lawyer for Andrew Cuomo, was identified in a report as having advised the former governor on how to handle sex harassment allegations.
content: Alphonso David, the president of the Human Rights Campaign, the nation’s largest L.G.B.T.Q. advocacy organization, was ousted by the group’s board on Monday night over a report revealing that he had advised former Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo on how to handle sex harassment allegations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Fall Restaurant Preview: A Reboot for New York
description: Restaurants whose plans were put on hold by the pandemic finally emerge, while global powerhouses gain footholds in Manhattan.
content: New York City’s fall restaurant season will effectively be the first in two years, and though Covid is a wild card, chefs and restaurateurs are forging ahead with openings and reopenings, often resuming projects that have been on hold. Ambitious restaurants in the heart of Manhattan from Union Square to 59th Street, like Le Pavillon and Iris, have been up and running, with new places set to join them. Prominent players like Danny Meyer, Laurent Tourondel, Ignacio Mattos and Franklin Becker are expanding their portfolios. Rick Bayless of Chicago, and Will Beckett and Huw Gott of London’s Hawksmoor are all making New York debuts. New steakhouses are still arriving, and Indian food, both fast-casual and formal, continues to get fresh attention. Despite the loss of some marquee names, there are signs of life in Hudson Yards. High-end sushi bars keep opening. And so far, despite the challenges of staffing and getting supplies delivered, the openings appear to be happening on time — a departure from past years, when many were delayed for months. That may be an index of how eager the owners are to get back to business.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: Return to campus in the U.S.
content: In-person classes are returning to almost every university in the United States after more than a year of crisis and chaos — and at a particularly fraught moment. The highly contagious Delta variant is pushing cases skyward while the polarized debate around vaccines and masks has complicated campus discussions about virus safety.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Spencer Bokat-Lindell
title: Climate Disaster Is the New Normal. Can We Save Ourselves?
description: There are only two options: adapt or suffer.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Ezra Klein Show'
title: Can We Change Our Sexual Desires? Should We?
description: The philosopher Amia Srinivasan explores the complex interactions among desire, love and politics.
content: “Feminists have long dreamed of sexual freedom,” writes Amia Srinivasan. “What they refuse to accept is its simulacrum: sex that is said to be free not because it is equal but because it is ubiquitous.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman, Alan Rappeport and Jim Tankersley
title: Democrats and Lobbyists Gird for Battle Over Far-Reaching Tax Increases
description: Congressional committees this week begin drafting tax increases on the wealthy and corporations to pay for a $3.5 trillion social policy bill, but the targets are putting up a fight.
content: WASHINGTON — Congressional Democrats always knew their battle plan for raising taxes on corporations, large inheritances and the superwealthy would not survive initial contact with the enemy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Allen
title: 10 Hours Gives Us (Almost) All of Schumann’s Songs
description: Christian Gerhaher and Gerold Huber, peerless in lieder, have released an 11-disc set of Robert Schumann’s songs, many overlooked.
content: Back in 1988, it was hearing the lieder of Robert Schumann that convinced Christian Gerhaher, then a philosophy student in Munich, to ask a pianist he knew from school, Gerold Huber, whether they might start playing some songs together.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Candace Jackson
title: House Hunting: Is This Price Right?
description: In parts of the San Francisco Bay Area, sellers deliberately underprice homes to spur bidding wars, leading to sales prices that can be double the list price.
content: Kim Rohrer was looking forward to leaving the leaky windows in the two-bedroom Berkeley rental duplex that she shared with her husband and two small children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Simon Romero
title: Booming Utah’s Weak Link: Surging Air Pollution
description: A red-hot economy, wildfire smoke from California and the shriveling of the Great Salt Lake are making Utah’s alarming pollution even worse.
content: SALT LAKE CITY — Kevin Perry had just begun his morning routine, stepping outside to get the newspaper, when he noticed something was wrong with the sky.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Taylor
title: Sally Rooney’s Novel of Letters Puts a Fresh Spin on Familiar Questions
description: “Beautiful World, Where Are You” asks readers to consider everything from the nature of fame to our place in the modern world.
content: BEAUTIFUL WORLD, WHERE ARE YOUBy Sally Rooney
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Howard University Hit by a Ransomware Attack
description: The Washington school canceled online and hybrid classes for a second day after shutting down its network.
content: Howard University, one of the country’s leading historically Black colleges and universities, canceled some classes for a second day after it was hit with a ransomware attack.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Egan
title: New to the American Melting Pot, and Finding Its Taste Bittersweet
description: In her memoir, “Beautiful Country,” Qian Julie Wang gives readers a child’s-eye view of what it’s like to find your way in a strange land.
content: Welcome to Group Text, a monthly column for readers and book clubs about the novels, memoirs and short-story collections that make you want to talk, ask questions and dwell in another world for a little bit longer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Eddy
title: With Her Party Fading, Merkel Dips Into the Campaign Fray
description: Germany’s chancellor pleaded with voters to support her party, which has flagging poll numbers and a candidate who has failed to capture imaginations.
content: BERLIN — Angela Merkel has said she wanted to stay out of the election campaign for her replacement as Germany’s chancellor. But with her party polling at record lows, Ms. Merkel used a speech to Germany’s Parliament on Tuesday to plead with Germans to keep the Christian Democrats in power.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Paton
title: Supermodels Speak Out Against Sexual Harassment
description: As former models prepare to offer testimony against Gérald Marie, their former agency boss, big names like Carla Bruni, Paulina Porizkova and Karen Elson are offering their support.
content: On the eve of fashion month, six women, all former models, flew into Paris from across the world — not to walk runways but to be interviewed by the child protection unit of the Paris police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Taliban, Mexico, Sally Rooney: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anemona Hartocollis
title: The Masked Professor vs. the Unmasked Student
description: At universities, some instructors are finding the return to the classroom a nerve-racking experience. A few have quit — one in the middle of class.
content: Matthew Boedy, an associate professor of rhetoric and composition, sent out a raw emotional appeal to his students at the University of North Georgia just before classes began: The Covid-19 Delta variant was rampaging through the state, filling up hospital beds. He would teach class in the equivalent of full body armor — vaccinated and masked.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Salamishah Tillet
title: Michael K. Williams Brought His Whole Life to His Characters
description: While Omar Little on “The Wire” is his best-known role, the actor drew upon his family and neighborhood for a slew of larger-than-life parts.
content: In a memorable scene in HBO’s “Lovecraft Country,” a sullen, swollen-eyed Montrose Freeman stands alone in a crowded underground ballroom as his lover, Sammy, in drag, beckons him to the dance floor. Wearing a red silk shirt, Montrose, played by Michael K. Williams, glistens as his character, a queer Black man, struggles with his sexuality and his race in 1950s Chicago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy Engle and Michael Gonchar
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘The U.S. War in Afghanistan: How It Started, and How It Ended’
description: In the lesson, students will learn more about America’s longest war — its causes and its consequences. Then, they will consider arguments for and against removing U.S. forces and debate: Should we have withdrawn from Afghanistan?
content: Featured Article: “The U.S. War in Afghanistan: How It Started, and How It Ended” by David Zucchino
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Man Gets 4 Years in $126 Million Printer Toner Fraud
description: Gilbert N. Michaels, of West Los Angeles, Calif., preyed on tens of thousands of small businesses and charities by overcharging them for toner they didn’t need, federal prosecutors said.
content: The sales script went something like this, federal prosecutors say: The price of printer toner has gone up, but customers can lock in at the lower rate they’ve been paying for the office supply.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Haag and Nicole Hong
title: 800,000 New Yorkers Just Lost Federal Unemployment Benefits
description: Many pandemic-era federal programs expired on Sunday, leaving jobless New Yorkers with more modest state unemployment benefits, or no aid at all.
content: From the beginning of the coronavirus pandemic, New York City has been pummeled economically unlike any other large American city, as a sustained recovery has failed to take root and hundreds of thousands of workers have yet to find full-time jobs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamie Fisher
title: Stuck With a Sick Parent in Hospital Hell
description: Lo Yi-Chin’s novel “Faraway” recounts a Taiwanese man’s struggle to get his father home from mainland China.
content: FARAWAYBy Lo Yi-Chin Translated by Jeremy Tiang
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: The Meadow Moves Across Town
description: The West Village chocolates and salts store closed a year ago, and will reopen on Mulberry Street.
content: A year ago, Mark Bitterman closed the Meadow, his West Village shop with its unusual inventory of chocolate bars, salts and bitters. After closing down during the pandemic, he has now relocated across town. At the deep, narrow store furnished with reclaimed lumber you can buy a different chocolate bar for almost every day of the year — he has a wall of more than 350 of them. And you could easily get lost exploring the more than 100 salts from various sources, many flavored, on the shelves opposite. Other products include fresh flowers, salt blocks for cooking and grilling, and a few grocery items like condiments and spices. Among the newer chocolates he’s carrying, almost all bean-to-bar, are Honeymoon from St. Louis, Bixby from Maine and Cuna de Piedra from Monterrey, Mexico. You might also get to know the elegant Sol Cacao bars from the Bronx. Among the salts are a saffron variety, a useful seasoning that’s difficult to produce, and a very popular Guatemalan fleur de sel and ground Tellicherry pepper mix, which isn’t.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mari Maeda and Yuji Oboshi
title: 9 Burgundy Accessories for Fall
description: Hit the perfect accent note with shoes and bags in a classic autumnal shade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Dolnick
title: For This Basketball Team, a Championship Was Just the First Challenge
description: In “Brothers on Three,” Abe Streep follows a high school basketball team through both a championship season and a reservation suicide epidemic.
content: BROTHERS ON THREEA True Story of Family, Resistance, and Hope on a Reservation in MontanaBy Abe Streep
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: A Hole, a Tunnel, a 32-Yard Crawl: Palestinians Still Free After Jailbreak
description: A huge manhunt has failed to find six Palestinian prisoners who escaped an Israeli jail early on Monday morning.
content: JERUSALEM — It was about 1:30 a.m. on Monday morning when the first prisoner poked his head up through a hole in a dirt track in northeast Israel and hauled himself above ground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: In ‘The Wonder Years,’ Dulé Hill Looks Forward, and Back
description: This reboot of the 1980s hit is still nostalgic, but it pushes Hill to confront themes that his previous TV parts have rarely allowed.
content: Dulé Hill joined “The West Wing” in 1999, not long after it debuted. He played Charlie Young, a personal aide who soon begins a relationship with the president’s youngest daughter, Zoey Bartlet (Elisabeth Moss). Charlie is Black; Zoey is white. The hate mail arrived almost immediately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Nxivm’s Second-in-Command Helped Build a Culture of Abuse, Survivors Say
description: As Nancy Salzman awaits sentencing, some who fell prey to the Nxivm cultlike group say Ms. Salzman’s enabling made the group’s misdeeds possible.
content: Three days after her recorded message played in a Brooklyn courtroom last fall, describing the lasting pain that the Nxivm cult leader Keith Raniere had inflicted on her, Ivy Nevares got a phone call.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: The Teenagers Are Taking Over Tennis. That Might Not End Well.
description: The U.S. Open play of Leylah Fernandez, Carlos Alcaraz and Emma Raducanu has been exhilarating. But if the past is prelude, rough seas are ahead.
content: It has been quite a run for the teenagers at the U.S. Open, especially a bright-eyed and beguiling troika that has managed to turn the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center into its personal playground.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Jacobs
title: Lawsuits Over ‘Misleading’ Food Labels Surge as Groups Cite Lax U.S. Oversight
description: A flurry of litigation by advocacy groups seeks to combat what they say is a rise in deceptive marketing by food giants.
content: Shoppers drawn to sustainable, humanely raised meat and dairy products could be forgiven for thinking the nation’s big food companies have turned away from the industrial farming practices that have long dominated American agriculture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Schuessler
title: Peter Singer Wins $1 Million Berggruen Prize
description: The philosopher, in keeping with his ideas about “effective altruism,” said he plans to donate half the prize to alleviating global poverty.
content: Over the past decade, the philosopher Peter Singer has been promoting the idea of “effective altruism,” which encourages people to have reason, rather than empathy, guide their philanthropy. It’s an idea that has sparked a movement on college campuses, in Silicon Valley and beyond.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura May Todd
title: Everything in Carla Sozzani’s Home Has a Story, Including Her Cat
description: The founder of the concept store 10 Corso Como has filled her Milan apartment with treasured pieces collected during her life in fashion.
content: It was the night the lights went out that Carla Sozzani realized just how influential she’d become. On that day in March 1999 — nine years after founding 10 Corso Como, arguably the world’s first concept store, on an unremarkable thoroughfare on the northern edge of Milan — she was putting the finishing touches on an exhibition in the space when the neighborhood went dark. “I called the city,” Sozzani recalls, “and they told me, ‘Carla, you’re going to be very happy, the power is off because the construction work has started. Corso Como is going to be a pedestrian street from now on.’” By putting down roots outside of Milan’s center, Sozzani had forced its fashionable shoppers out of their comfort zone, and like-minded businesses had followed suit. Suddenly, this tract of city was the most exciting place to be.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley, Wali Arian and Sami Sahak
title: Charter Flights Delayed as U.S. and Taliban Struggle to Work Together
description: With the Kabul airport closed, scores of people have tried to leave via the airport in the northern city of Mazar-i-Sharif. But the U.S. and the Taliban have struggled to establish an efficient system.
content: DOHA, Qatar — With the massive United States military effort to evacuate American citizens and endangered Afghans completed, those still scrambling to find safe passage from Afghanistan are now navigating a complicated and potentially dangerous diplomatic impasse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Jill Biden Returns to In-Person Teaching
description: Sending the first lady back into the classroom puts weight behind President Biden’s promise that his administration can get students safely back into in-person learning this fall.
content: WASHINGTON — Jill Biden, the first lady, quietly started another school year as an English professor on Tuesday, returning to the physical classroom after a year of teaching remotely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Apoorva Mandavilli
title: The Pandemic Has Set Back the Fight Against H.I.V., TB and Malaria
description: Prevention and treatment fell in poor countries last year as access to health care declined, according to a new report.
content: The Covid-19 pandemic has severely set back the fight against other global scourges like H.I.V., tuberculosis and malaria, according to a sobering new report released on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine Schulten
title: What’s It Like to Be Back in School?
description: If you’ve started, tell us about your experience. If you haven’t, tell us what you’re looking forward to, and what you’re not.
content: Maybe your school started in early August, like schools in Atlanta. Or maybe, like schools in New York City, your first day isn’t until mid-September. You might be wearing a mask or you might not. Or you might live in a place where the rules keep changing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Johnny Diaz
title: Mexico City to Replace Columbus Statue With Indigenous Woman Monument
description: “We owe it to them. We exist because of them,” the mayor of Mexico City said in a news conference.
content: A statue of the explorer Christopher Columbus that was removed last year in Mexico City will be replaced by a statue of an Indigenous woman to honor the country’s Native people, the mayor of Mexico City said on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Wudan Yan
title: Why Does Coffee Sometimes Make Me Tired?
description: Lethargy, blood sugar and dehydration explain in part the paradoxical effects of coffee on our energy levels.
content: Caffeine, the main active ingredient in coffee, has a well-justified reputation for being an energy booster. But caffeine is also a drug, which means that it can affect each of us differently, depending on our consumption habits and our genes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kara Swisher
title: The Medium of the Moment
description: Newsletters are a natural evolution of the creator-fan relationship.
content: This is a preview of the Kara Swisher newsletter, which is reserved for Times subscribers. Sign up to get it in your inbox twice a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: deft
description: This word has appeared in 138 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: One in 5,000
description: The real chances of a breakthrough infection.
content: The C.D.C. reported a terrifying fact in July: Vaccinated people with the Delta variant of the Covid virus carried roughly the same viral load in their noses and throats as unvaccinated people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor and Tiffany May
title: Ohio Judge Reverses Order Requiring Covid Patient to Be Given Ivermectin
description: An intubated patient was prescribed the deworming drug by his doctor. Federal health officials have said that it has not been shown to be effective against the coronavirus and that it can be toxic in humans.
content: An Ohio judge on Monday reversed an earlier decision requiring a hospital to administer ivermectin, an anti-parasitic drug that is primarily used as a veterinary deworming agent, to a patient as a treatment for Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘My First Love Called Me a Vacation’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: Anna was the manager of the Tucson, Ariz., assisted living home where my father lived. The day father moved in, I told her I wanted to rearrange the furniture. She had already done it when I arrived. She cut his toenails, combed his hair, watched sports and “Leave It to Beaver” with him, and played his Bible audiobook as he navigated his last days on earth. I loved him. She loved him. Neither of us had been in love with a woman before. But she said, “There’s a first time for everything.” In an ending, a new beginning. — Holly Schaffer
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers and Juliet Macur
title: Calling ‘Code Red’ on Climate, Biden Pushes for Infrastructure Plan
description: “The nation and the world are in peril,” the president said during a stop in a hard-hit borough of New York City. “And that’s not hyperbole. That is a fact.”
content: President Biden warned Americans on Tuesday that Hurricane Ida’s lethal destruction was the sure sign of a nation and world “in peril” from climate change and said drastic action would be needed to prevent extreme weather patterns from worsening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Darryn King
title: With a Mess of Fabrics, Broadway’s Costume Shops Return to Work
description: During the pandemic they helped by sewing cloth masks and surgical gowns. Now, they are back in a frenzy to make theater sparkle.
content: The work spaces at Parsons-Meares Ltd., one of New York City’s premier costume shops for Broadway shows, tend to be a spectacular confusion of satin and silk, lace and lamé, milliskin and muslin, scraps of brown paper in unique and strange shapes. Each surface seems on the verge of being inundated by leftover materials of varying hues and textures.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Beautiful Country,’ by Qian Julie Wang: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from “Beautiful Country,” by Qian Julie Wang
content: My story starts decades before my birth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: She’s Green. She’s Young. And She Wants to Change Germany.
description: Annalena Baerbock, the 40-year-old candidate for the Green Party, is likely to have a say in Germany’s next government, no matter who wins this month’s election.
content: BOCHUM, Germany — The woman who wants to replace Chancellor Angela Merkel strode onto the stage in sneakers and a leather jacket, behind her the steel skeleton of a disused coal mining tower, before her a sea of expectant faces. The warm-up act, a guy with an Elvis quiff draped in a rainbow flag, sang “Imagine.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jin Yu Young and Chau Doan
title: A Vietnamese court sentences a man to five years in prison for breaking coronavirus rules.
description: The man failed to self-quarantine as required after returning home from Ho Chi Minh City and did not report his travel history on official forms, a state-run newspaper said, and one of the people he infected died.
content: A man who returned to his home in southern Vietnam after traveling to Ho Chi Minh City for work received a five-year prison sentence on Tuesday for spreading the coronavirus, state news media reported.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John McWhorter
title: On Matters of Race, Randall Kennedy Demands Thinking Over Feeling
description: Kennedy’s new essay collection, “Say It Loud!,” challenges many common beliefs in the name of individuality.
content: SAY IT LOUD!On Race, Law, History, and CultureBy Randall Kennedy
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Streitfeld
title: In Silicon Valley, Criminal Prosecutors See No Evil
description: The Elizabeth Holmes fraud trial is set to be a major spectacle, but tech executives generally get a pass when it comes to wrongdoing.
content: SAN FRANCISCO — The coronavirus pandemic has helped Silicon Valley companies in many ways, from bringing them hordes of new customers to weakening the competition to juicing the bottom line.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: The lead proponent of Newsom’s recall has been sidelined with the coronavirus.
description: Orrin Heatlie, who along with a small group of Tea Party activists began circulating petitions for the governor’s recall in 2019, said he was recovering at home from the virus.
content: As the pandemic-fueled campaign to recall Gov. Gavin Newsom of California heads into its last week, its lead proponent said he has been sidelined with the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Molly Fischer
title: Moving to New York With Little Cash but Charm to Spare
description: “Happy Hour,” a debut novel by Marlowe Granados, follows a pair of thrifty, stylish and nimble young women navigating the big city.
content: HAPPY HOURBy Marlowe Granados
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andre Dubus III
title: His Mother Is Terminally Ill. His Father, a Mystery.
description: In Atticus Lish’s second novel, “The War for Gloria,” a teenage boy shoulders grueling family hardships.
content: THE WAR FOR GLORIABy Atticus Lish
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Winston Choi-Schagrin
title: Medical Journals Call Climate Change the ‘Greatest Threat to Global Public Health’
description: An editorial published by more than 200 journals worldwide warned of ‘catastrophic harm to health that will be impossible to reverse.’
content: A collection of leading health and medical journals called this week for swift action to combat climate change, calling on governments to cooperate and invest in the environmental crisis with the degree of funding and urgency they used to confront the coronavirus pandemic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Vineyard
title: Where to Stream Michael K. Williams’s Best TV Performances
description: Starting with “The Wire,” Williams explored provocative intersections of race, crime, sexuality and masculinity. But he wasn’t afraid to poke fun at his own image.
content: Omar didn’t scare easily, and neither did Michael K. Williams.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alice Newell-Hanson, Bruno Staub and Delphine Danhier
title: Véronique Nichanian Makes Clothes for the Thinking Man
description: The longtime artistic director of Hermès’s men’s universe has perfected her craft, designing clothes as easy as they are meticulous.
content: “YOU KNOW,” SAYS Véronique Nichanian, “if I were 20, I would dye it green or pink.” It’s a warm June afternoon in Paris, the kind when the sun makes the rooftops of the city’s limestone buildings look as if they’ve been dipped in gold, and we’re sitting beneath a pergola on a small strip of lawn behind the Hôtel d’Ecquevilly, a grand 17th-century mansion in the Marais. Nichanian, 67, is talking about her hair. Throughout her 33-year tenure at Hermès, where she is currently the artistic director of what the brand calls its men’s universe (which encompasses not only the two annual clothing collections but also shoes, accessories and watches), she has maintained its natural shade of glossy chestnut and worn it in a long, layered bob. But recently she has been inspired by the girls she sees walking around the city with vivid neon manes. While Nichanian — who is wearing a crisp white shirt, dark boot-cut jeans and a few pieces of simple silver jewelry — may outwardly embody the tenets of classic Parisian good taste, she has always prized, as she puts it, “people who are one step to the side.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eduardo Medina
title: Developers Plan to Demolish Al Capone’s Mansion. Some Want It Preserved.
description: The gangster’s former refuge on Palm Island, Fla., near Miami Beach, is dividing residents and city officials: Should it be razed to make way for a modern home?
content: The mansion, on an island off Miami Beach, befitted the Prohibition-era crime leader: pearl white walls, a cabana for pool parties and a guesthouse for armed guards on the payroll to keep a look out for their boss, Al Capone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael S. Schmidt
title: Democrats Press Biden Administration to Take On Texas Abortion Law
description: House Democrats urged the Justice Department to prosecute anyone who tries to sue those who help women seeking abortions.
content: Democrats and reproductive rights activists pressed the Biden administration on Tuesday to take more aggressive action to stop a Texas law that prohibits abortions after six weeks of pregnancy, even as administration officials and legal experts acknowledged it would be difficult to curtail the law in the coming months.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Igor Oistrakh, Soviet-Era Violinist (and a Son of One), Dies at 90
description: His father, David, was one of the 20th century’s finest violinists, but Igor more than held his own as a musician and interpreter performing throughout the West.
content: Igor Oistrakh, a noted violinist who was part of a violin-playing family that included his father, David, one of the 20th century’s finest exponents of the instrument, died on Aug. 14 in Moscow. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna P. Kambhampaty
title: A T-Shirt Shop for the Semi-Ironic ‘Twilight’ Fan
description: BUGGIRL200 started out as an inside joke. But easy-to-use e-commerce platforms like Shopify have made it possible to turn such jokes into full-fledged businesses.
content: Before 2020, Madison Sinclair hadn’t seen any of the “Twilight” movies. But after watching all five during quarantine, she grew completely enamored — and inspired to express her new fandom.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Erdbrink
title: To Avoid River Flooding, Go With the Flow, the Dutch Say
description: Extreme rainfall is causing deadly and destructive floods globally. The Netherlands averted disaster this summer by creating flood plains.
content: The Netherlands, accustomed to wet weather, was midway through what would become one of the wettest Julys on record, and Patrick van der Broeck was getting edgy.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: TUESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Douglas Schorzman
title: Who Are the Taliban’s New Government Leaders? Here’s What We Know
description: Many of the acting cabinet ministers appointed Tuesday have played similar roles within the Taliban for years, but there were some surprises.
content: The Taliban formally declared a caretaker government on Tuesday, appointing acting cabinet ministers who were largely loyalists from the group’s first years of rule in the 1990s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas L. Friedman
title: What Comes After the War on Terrorism? War on China?
description: Is conflict with China inevitable?
content: The U.S. withdrawal from Afghanistan after a failed 20-year nation-building exercise has left many Americans and analysts saying, “If only we knew back then what we know now, we would have never gone down that path.” I am not sure that’s true, but it nevertheless raises this question: What are we doing today in foreign policy that we might look back 20 years from now and say, “If only we knew back then what we know now, we would never have gone down that path”?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Mozur
title: Alibaba Manager Accused of Rape Is Released, Adding to China’s #MeToo Debate
description: Prosecutors declined to charge the man, who a co-worker said had assaulted her, an allegation that highlighted sexism in the Chinese tech scene.
content: The police in China released a former Alibaba manager who had been accused of rape by a co-worker after prosecutors declined to charge him, deepening debate about an episode that has shaken the Chinese technology industry and prompted a reckoning for the fledgling #MeToo movement in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Adlai E. Stevenson III, Ex-Senator and Scion of Formidable Political Family, Dies at 90
description: The Illinois Democrat served a decade in the United States Senate: “It was ordained at birth that I would go into a life of public service.”
content: Adlai E. Stevenson III, a scion of generations of Illinois Democrats, who shared the names and presidential ambitions of his father and great-grandfather but not their political successes, serving a decade in the Senate and losing two races for governor, died on Monday at his home in Chicago. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Dyja
title: How One New York Firefighter Remembers 9/11 — and What He Learned
description: Joseph Pfeifer was a battalion chief on 9/11, and his memoir, “Ordinary Heroes,” vividly describes the day as seen by someone at ground zero.
content: ORDINARY HEROESA Memoir of 9/11By Joseph Pfeifer
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Casey Parks
title: The Tragedy of America’s Rural Schools
description: Outdated textbooks, not enough teachers, no ventilation — for millions of kids like Harvey Ellington, the public-education system has failed them their whole lives.
content: One Saturday afternoon in late May, a few days before the end of his junior year, Harvey Ellington plopped onto his queen-size bed, held up his phone and searched for a signal. The 17-year-old lived in a three-bedroom trailer on an acre lot surrounded by oak trees, too far into the country for broadband, but eventually his cell found the hot spot his high school had lent him for the year. He opened his email and began to type.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Vognar
title: In ‘American Rust,’ Buildings Crumble, Passions Burn
description: Set amid the Rust Belt towns of Western Pennsylvania, the new series, starring Jeff Daniels and Maura Tierney, tells a story of good people and bad choices.
content: The setting is both beautiful and ugly, resplendent and run-down. Green foliage wraps around rusting mills, no longer in use; steep hills drop off to the river, like the plummeting dreams of local residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel E. Slotnik and Adeel Hassan
title: The U.S. surpasses 40 million known coronavirus cases.
description: As the fall begins, hospitalizations and new deaths are high, though they remain lower than last winter’s peaks.
content: More than 40 million cases of the coronavirus have been recorded in the United States, according to a New York Times database.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: ‘The Big Book of Amaro’ Chronicles the World of the Bitter Spirit
description: Everything is covered in an encyclopedic new book by Matteo Zed, an Italian spirits expert.
content: In an encyclopedic new book, the Italian amari expert Matteo Zed covers the spirit, the bitter drink as old as monasteries and made new in Brooklyn. Amari are sipped as digestivos, aperitivos and in cocktails. He tells their history, describes the 50 botanicals often used when making them, gives an idea of their styles and sorts them into categories. There’s an amaro renaissance going on worldwide and he helps it along, with his favorite ways to enjoy the spirit. There are descriptions of more than 200 Italian brands, a fascinating region-by-region and bottle-by-bottle survey, followed by a handful of amari from other countries. The book supplies recipes for cocktails using amari and a few dishes made with them, all beautifully photographed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthieu Aikins and Jim Huylebroek
title: Taliban Appoint Stalwarts to Top Government Posts
description: The Taliban’s violent response to the latest demonstration, which included hundreds of women in Kabul, was another sign that they will not tolerate peaceful dissent in Afghanistan.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — The Taliban announced a caretaker government on Tuesday, taking a major step in re-establishing their Islamic Emirate of Afghanistan, and empowering many of the movement’s stalwarts from their regime in the 1990s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mary Tuma
title: Texas’ Long History of Hollowing Out Women’s Health Care
description: It’s a watershed moment in  a long-running war on reproductive rights in the state.
content: In a stunning move, the U.S. Supreme Court allowed a sweeping law to take effect in Texas last week that eradicates nearly all abortion care in the second-largest state in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: There’s Something About Miso
description: This pantry staple leads to big, umami-rich flavor in pastas, soups and vegetable dishes.
content: Years ago, at a New York restaurant called Nishi, I tried a cheeky, cheeseless version of cacio e pepe made with chickpea miso. I was skeptical, but the hot, slippery noodles were so satisfying, so full of salty dimension and depth, so absurdly delicious, that I didn’t miss the cheese at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jon Pareles
title: Bomba Estéreo Strives to Save the Planet and Soothe the Heart
description: Mixing traditions and electronics, this duo from Colombia envisions a futurism with roots.
content: When Bomba Estéreo, the Colombian duo of Simón Mejía and Liliana Saumet, had nearly finished recording its sixth studio album, “Deja,” the group took part in an age-old ritual: a pagamento, or payment. It’s a ceremony “to pay back what you have taken from the Earth,” Mejía explained in a video interview from his home studio in Bogotá.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Abbott Signs Texas Election Law, Ending a Fierce Voting Rights Battle
description: Gov. Greg Abbott called the law, which will sharply curtail access to the ballot in Texas, a “paradigm” for other states looking to pass election bills.
content: Gov. Greg Abbott of Texas on Tuesday signed a sweeping bill overhauling the state’s elections, capping a dramatic, monthslong national saga over voting rights with a new Republican-led law that will sharply restrict voting across the nation’s second-biggest state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kristen Bayrakdarian
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $4.19 MILLION
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Parini
title: Colm Toibin Imagines the Life of Thomas Mann in ‘The Magician’
description: Toibin’s new novel is a survey of the German writer’s monumental career, complicated family life and hidden sexuality.
content: THE MAGICIANBy Colm Toibin
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Hanna Ingber
title: Divorce Stinks, But It Could Be Your Superpower
description: A divorced mother of two finds a new sense of pride in learning how to manage a home and much more, on her own.
content: Three years ago, as I contemplated ending my marriage, I looked out my kitchen window and saw my husband mowing our lawn. I didn’t yet know if I’d be able to manage on my own, living in the New Jersey suburbs as a divorced mother of two. Yes, I had spent years alone when I was younger. As a journalist, I had even moved to Myanmar and India by myself. But this was different. Could I manage a house alone? Could I mow the lawn?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Medina and Jill Cowan
title: Latinos Shape California. Why Are So Many Sitting Out the Recall?
description: As Gov. Gavin Newsom faces a recall election, he has struggled to connect with Hispanic voters, who make up nearly a third of the electorate.
content: LOS ANGELES — The political power of Latinos has never been stronger in California.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: Another Failed Presidency at Hand
description: It starts by acknowledging the gravity of his blunders.
content: This Sept. 11, a diminished president will preside over a diminished nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Steinhauer
title: Veterans Struggle With Issues That Are Often Invisible to Others
description: Those who served in the wars that began after Sept. 11, 2001, are struggling with health problems, trauma and feelings of displacement and alienation.
content: WASHINGTON — Melissa Gauntner, a retired Army first sergeant, has at times been gripped with panic and has trouble socializing beyond close friends, the result of dual traumas: years of sexual assault and harassment in the military, and mine explosions she saw in Afghanistan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yanzhong Huang
title: China Doesn’t Want to ‘Live With’ Covid. But It May Have To.
description: The benefits of the zero-infections policy have dropped in relation to the costs of implementation, and there are signs it is becoming counterproductive.
content: “How lucky I was born in China,” a young Chinese scholar declared last month in his WeChat. He was proud: Following the worst domestic Covid-19 outbreak since Wuhan, China had brought daily new case counts down to a few dozen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A New Food Hall for Midtown
description: The Hugh, with a generous central seating area rimmed with trees, will have 17 restaurants, bars and food retailers.
content: Hugh Stubbins, the architect of a landmark skyscraper with an angled roof at Lexington Avenue and 53rd Street, now has his name emblazoned over the entrance to a spacious and soaring new food hall called the Hugh, which occupies the heart of the building’s ground floor. Originally the Citicorp Center and now owned by Boston Properties, the building opened in 1977 and had an atrium filled with shops and stands, an unusual feature that was described as “a U.N. of food” in The Times. That space has been renewed and refreshed. Around the perimeter of a generous central seating area rimmed with trees are 17 restaurants, bars and food retailers, an eclectic collection, all with counter service and many with bar stools. They’re opening gradually starting this week and offer a snapshot of today’s appetite. “We see a younger clientele in this neighborhood, people who go downtown or back to Brooklyn after work, so we’re trying to capture a sense of downtown,” said Anna Castellani, who created DeKalb Market Hall in Brooklyn, and this food hall with David Swinghamer in partnership with Boston Properties. She emphasized that they wanted to provide a more elegant setting than typical food halls. “We tried to be true to the building,” she said. There is also some outdoor seating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier, Boryana Dzhambazova and Monika Pronczuk
title: A Vaccine Success in Europe That Sinks in the East
description: Partly because of skepticism about shots, Bulgaria has fully inoculated only 20 percent of adults, and Romania 32 percent, well below the European Union average of 70 percent.
content: BRUSSELS — More than 70 percent of the European Union’s adult population has been fully vaccinated, making it one of the world’s vaccination leaders. But some Eastern European countries are lagging far behind, exposing the bloc to new waves of infections and creating a divide that E.U. officials and experts say could hamper recovery efforts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Flávia Milhorance and Ernesto Londoño
title: Pro-Bolsonaro Rallies May Be Prelude to Power Grab, Critics Say
description: Critics see in the rhetoric of the leader, who is seeing declining poll numbers and mounting legal challenges, a parallel to former President Donald J. Trump’s.
content: RIO DE JANEIRO — Beleaguered by declining poll numbers, a sputtering economy and judicial investigations, President Jair Bolsonaro called on his supporters to rally across the country on Tuesday, Brazil’s Independence Day, in a show of force critics fear could be a prelude to a power grab.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Grattan
title: A Heart-Rending Novel About an Intersex Teenager Forced to Live as a Boy
description: In her debut, “An Ordinary Wonder,” Buki Papillon explores the complex, and often painful, experiences of a Nigerian teenager forced to deny her identity.
content: AN ORDINARY WONDERBy Buki Papillon
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabelia Herrera
title: Mas Aya’s Music Holds Quiet Rebellions
description: On his new album, the Nicaraguan Canadian producer considers the political expressions embedded in moments of stillness.
content: Brandon Valdivia’s “Momento Presente” is like a summons. On the arresting track from his September album, “Máscaras,” an offbeat, not-quite-footwork rhythm thumps under the swirls of a tin whistle. A bell chimes, and before long, the godlike voice of an elder intones a call to action. “Right now, the oppressors and the oppressed are being separated,” it reflects in Spanish. “We’re not going to wait 2,000 years for the good ones to be on one side and the bad ones to be on another. We are living in that moment now.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reid J. Epstein
title: When Will Trump Answer the Big 2024 Question?
description: The field of would-be Republican candidates remains frozen while the former president decides his next moves.
content: Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Abrams
title: Quarterbacks Are the N.F.L.’s Biggest Investment. Why Won’t It Listen to Them?
description: From Aaron Rodgers to Tom Brady to Patrick Mahomes, quarterbacks are trying to push football’s status quo. The results have lagged behind stars’ achievements in other sports.
content: Aaron Rodgers had a lot to get off his mind.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Lyall
title: The History of Dreams, From Greek Mythology to Last Night’s Sleep
description: In “The Oracle of Night,” Sidarta Ribeiro makes a resounding case for the mystery, beauty and cognitive importance of dreams.
content: In the winter of 1995, the Brazilian neuroscientist Sidarta Ribeiro moved to New York to pursue his Ph.D. at Rockefeller University. His arrival, he writes in his fascinating, discursive new book, “The Oracle of Night,” precipitated one of the strangest periods of his life.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Miss the Old Kanye? Try the New Kanye.
description: West has always been dreaming big, speaking loudly, courting controversy and channeling all of that into music. But one thing has changed.
content: Kanye West’s 10th album, “Donda,” just had the biggest opening week of the year (though that mark is about to be eclipsed by Drake’s “Certified Lover Boy”). The success of “Donda” on the Billboard chart and on streaming services wasn’t guaranteed, given how West has receded from the center of hip-hop in recent years. But with an album rollout that grew increasingly rococo over several weeks, he displayed his true gift for garnering attention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: September Will Be Hot. Here’s How to Protect Your Pets (and Yourself).
description: Extreme temperatures can be deadly.
content: For much of California, the arrival of September has brought extreme, scalding temperatures.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Reminisce About the Restaurant Savoy
description: The East Village restaurant Huertas will host a conversation with the chef Peter Hoffman about restaurants and his memoir.
content: If you’re among those who might pass the corner of Prince and Crosby Streets in SoHo with a pang of nostalgia for the loss of the restaurant Savoy, closed in 2011, you can relive some of its moments with Peter Hoffman, the chef and a former owner, at a program at the Basque restaurant Huertas, near Mr. Hoffman’s restaurant Back Forty, which closed in 2014. On Sept. 23, Jonah Miller, the owner of Huertas, will hold a conversation with Mr. Hoffman about restaurants and his book, “What’s Good? A Memoir in 14 Ingredients,” which will be on sale. Savoy-inspired snacks and wine will be served. Proof of vaccination is required.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Oscar Lopez and Ephrat Livni
title: In Global First, El Salvador Adopts Bitcoin as Currency
description: President Nayib Bukele has promoted the cryptocurrency as a path to financial freedom, but economic experts and many Salvadorans worry the move brings great risks.
content: MEXICO CITY — El Salvador on Tuesday became the first country to adopt Bitcoin as legal tender, allowing the cryptocurrency to be used in any transaction, from buying a cup of coffee to paying taxes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Inflation Is Popping From Sydney to San Francisco. It May Be a Good Sign.
description: Inflation has surged across advanced economies. The shared experience underlines that price gains come from temporary drivers — for now.
content: Price gains are shooting higher across many advanced economies as consumer demand, shortages and other pandemic-related factors combine to fuel a burst of inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Mark Duplass Can’t Get Enough of ‘Rocky II’
description: The filmmaker and star of “Language Lessons” discusses his teenage education in indie cinema and the screenwriting lessons in “Waiting For Godot.”
content: It was May 2020, two months into lockdown, and Mark Duplass, an avowed workaholic, was getting itchy. So he took up some hobbies, one of which was conversational Spanish lessons with an online institute in Guatemala.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Rachel Lindsay Has No Roses Left to Burn
description: I thought I could change The Bachelor franchise from within. Until I realized I was their token.
content: I thought I could change The Bachelor franchise from within. Until I realized I was their token.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Gossiping With Tabloid Icon Cindy Adams
description: The stalwart of the New York Post gets ready to tell all — kind of.
content: The stalwart of the New York Post gets ready to tell all — kind of.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Plague Is an Apocalypse. But It Can Bring a New World.
description: The meaning of this one is in our hands.
content: The meaning of this one is in our hands.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Alec Baldwin Gets Under Trump’s Skin
description: Comedy and tragedy in an age of political chaos.
content: Comedy and tragedy in an age of political chaos.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times Food Desk
title: How Eating Out Has Changed, From the Menu to the Tip
description: Early-bird dinners, sturdier pizzas, noisier streets: The pandemic has brought a host of new developments that could last awhile.
content: Early-bird dinners, sturdier pizzas, noisier streets: The pandemic has brought a host of new developments that could last awhile.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Prices are Going Up. Will It Last?
description: You may have noticed that you’re paying more for lots of things. Inflation has become a hot topic, but the question is whether it will last.
content: You may have noticed that you’re paying more for lots of things. Inflation has become a hot topic, but the question is whether it will last.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Connecticut Home With No Uninvited Guests
description: After spending $40,000 to get rid of an army of mice, they could finally start thinking about updating their new house.
content: After spending $40,000 to get rid of an army of mice, they could finally start thinking about updating their new house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Burke
title: Frank Conversations About Making a Living in Dance
description: The choreographer Miguel Gutierrez’s podcast “Are You for Sale?” looks at what he calls “the ethical entanglements between art and money.”
content: On the first episode of his new podcast “Are You for Sale?,” the choreographer Miguel Gutierrez divulges the salary he paid himself during what he calls “one of the high points” of his career. The big reveal? Forty-eight thousand dollars a year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Should Sirhan Sirhan, Robert Kennedy’s Assassin, Be Freed?
description: Readers offer differing opinions, citing the historical impact of Kennedy’s murder and the need to move away from revenge. Also: Pro-Trump lawyers; dress codes.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

title: 9/11 Reflections: We’d Like to Hear From You
description: We ask readers how the attack affected them.
content: As the 20th anniversary of 9/11 approaches, we ask readers to reflect on how the attacks affected your life directly or changed your view of the world around you.
source.name: The New York Times
